prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors considered by the Panel—Advancement of cases already assigned to judge

para.paratext: The Panel appears to attach great significance to the advancement of related cases on the docket of a potential judge. This factor is one that is probably most significant due more to correlation with case management factors than from being directly related to them, but it is significant nonetheless.

The advancement of the related cases already pending before a judge is related to specific concerns of the Panel in numerous ways.[1] Transfer of cases to the judge whose cases are most advanced may result in the most expeditious resolution of the litigation. This would occur because the additional cases would presumably engender accelerated discovery and pretrial preparation to “catch up” to the pending cases rather than pending cases being held up. Transfer to another district would be more likely to result in the more advanced cases “waiting” for the pending cases to be prepared for trial. A judge presiding over cases that have advanced further in pretrial proceedings is also presumably more experienced in the cases just by being more likely to have considered and decided more questions.[2] Although the Panel has not directly stated so, greater relative advancement of the cases may reflect greater skill at managing complex litigation, also making the judge with the advanced calendar more suitable to handle the entire litigation.[3] The Panel has transferred cases so that they could all be heard by a judge considering a settlement agreement in the cases pending in that court.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See, e.g., In re Progressive Corp. Ins. Underwriting & Rating Practices Litigation, 259 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2003). The role advancement of cases plays in the selection of a transferee district is discussed in § 6:16.
See In re Seeburg-Commonwealth United Merger, 312 F. Supp. 909, 911 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
See In re Medco Health Solutions, Inc., 254 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
